item.title: On the genus Alisphaera (Alisphaeraceae, Haptophyta) including a new species A. Memoria sp. nov. in the South China Sea
item.description:
On the genus Alisphaera (Alisphaeraceae, Haptophyta) including a new species A. Memoria sp. nov. in the South China Sea

Doan-Nhu, Hai; Nguyen-Ngoc, Lam
Nova Hedwigia, (2021), p. 281 - 290

Abstract

Genus Alisphaera including 9 species and was not often reported in different waters. During our investigation of coccolithophorid assemblages in the South China Sea, two species of this genus were found, Alisphaera gaudii and A. memoria sp. nov. The new species is morphologically related to the type species, A. ordinata and to A. capulata because the two parts of the distal flange overlap. A. memoria is primarily characterised by a large and very well developed vertical part of the distal flange, which is about 3 times wider than the horizontal part, and one of the elements of the vertical part of the distal flange usually has a spine.

item.title: Mallomonas siderea sp. nov. (Synurales, Chrysophyceae), a new tropical species from the section Torquatae
item.description:
Mallomonas siderea sp. nov. (Synurales, Chrysophyceae), a new tropical species from the section Torquatae

Gusev, Evgeniy; Kulikovskiy, Maxim
Nova Hedwigia, (2021), p. 291 - 301

Abstract

Mallomonas siderea sp. nov. is described from Vietnam based on silica-scale morphology studied with transmission and scanning electron microscopy. This species is similar to taxa from the Mallomonas pumilio group and is characterized by small scales with large or small annular and horseshoe-shaped rimmed pits on the shield. Delicate papillae, oriented longitudinally with the scale border on anterior submarginal ribs and joined by ribs in triangular net on the shield, are also characteristic features for the new species. Scales of Mallomonas siderea were found in two localities from two provinces of Northern and Central Vietnam.

item.title: A new species of Ceratolejeunea (Marchantiophyta, Lejeuneaceae) from Cuba
item.description:
A new species of Ceratolejeunea (Marchantiophyta, Lejeuneaceae) from Cuba

Dauphin L., Gregorio; Cañiza Ovelar, Bernardo D.; Bastos, Cid Jose Passos
Nova Hedwigia, (2021), p. 303 - 309

Abstract

A new species of Ceratolejeunea (Spruce) J.B.Jack et Steph. from Baracoa, Cuba is described and illustrated. The diagnostic characters of Ceratolejeunea baracoensis are its combination of moniliate and seriate ocelli on single leaves, leaf and underleaf margins with weak denticulations formed by the projecting corners of two adjacent cells (Allorgella-type denticulations), underleaves bifid to 2/3, underleaf lobes lanceolate, 4 cells wide at base and 6–7 cells long.

item.title: “Giant males” in Fissidens (Bryophyta) from arid areas: The case of F. eremicus and F. sublimbatus
item.description:
“Giant males” in Fissidens (Bryophyta) from arid areas: The case of F. eremicus and F. sublimbatus

Guerra, Juan; Jiménez, Juan A.; Cano, María J.
Nova Hedwigia, (2021), p. 311 - 322

Abstract

Fissidens sublimbatus Grout, a species described from North America, and the recently described F. eremicus J. Guerra & J.A. Jiménez, known from southern Iberian Peninsula, North Africa and the Canary Islands, are characterized by the presence of dimorphic stems. The smallest stems, with 4–5(6) pairs of leaves are female fronds with archegonia and/or sporophytes, and the largest ones, with up to 22 pairs of leaves in F. sublimbatus, have been described as sterile fronds in this species. A meticulous study of the larger stems in both species, involving careful extraction of the stems from the soil and subsequent washing by shaking and centrifugation, has shown that these larger fronds correspond to male plants which carry perigonia at their base. In both species, the male stems have more or less buried perigonia with a very short perigonial branch and generally immature perigonia, hardly visible, or sometimes in pairs or isolated on a long and well-developed perigonial branch. Finally, it has been shown that the partially buried stems can sprout from one year to the next and regenerate isolated or small groups of perigonia. Therefore, a new sexual system is reported in the diverse typology of sexual structures in Fissidens Hedw.

item.title: Identification of Acrodontium luzulae and Ramularia coleosporii, two fungicolous fungi on Melampsora hypericorum, the causal agent of Hypericum androsaemum rust
item.description:
Identification of Acrodontium luzulae and Ramularia coleosporii, two fungicolous fungi on Melampsora hypericorum, the causal agent of Hypericum androsaemum rust

Bakhshi, Mounes; Zare, Rasoul; Jafary, Hossein
Nova Hedwigia, (2021), p. 323 - 337

Abstract

In a survey of foliar fungal plant diseases in the north of Iran, several fungicolous fungal isolates were recovered from uredinia of Melampsora hypericorum on leaves of Hypericum androsaemum. Integration of cultural and morphological characteristics with sequence data from the LSU, ITS, actA, tef1 and gapdh loci were applied to identify the isolates. The isolates were identified as two species of hyphomycetous fungi including Acrodontium luzulae and Ramularia coleosporii. Both species were identified and recorded here for the first time on M. hypericorum rust. Additionally, the genus Acrodontium and the species R. coleosporii represent new records for the mycobiota of Iran and the species A. luzulae represents new record for the mycobiota of Asia. This paper provides a full description and illustration for these species.

item.title: Porodaedalea himalayensis and P. indica from Pakistan
item.description:
Porodaedalea himalayensis and P. indica from Pakistan

Bashir, Humaira; Jabeen, Sana; Khalid, Abdul Nasir
Nova Hedwigia, (2021), p. 339 - 351

Abstract

Basidiomata were collected from Fairy Meadows, Gilgit-Baltistan and Margala Hills, Islamabad, Pakistan during routine field tours and analyzed on the basis of morphological and molecular phylogenetic analysis by using the DNA sequences of internal transcribed spacer regions of the nuclear ribosomal RNA genes. The specimens were found morphologically similar to Porodaedalea himalayensis and P. indica and molecular phylogenetic tree supported their positions with already known P. himalayensis and P. indica. Porodaedalea himalayensis represents first record from Pakistan and P. indica is being reported for the first time from Islamabad, the capital territory.

item.title: First occurrence of the rare coprophilous mycoparasitic Syncephalis plumigaleata (Zoopagales, Piptocephalidaceae) in South America
item.description:
First occurrence of the rare coprophilous mycoparasitic Syncephalis plumigaleata (Zoopagales, Piptocephalidaceae) in South America

Cruz, Mateus Oliveira da; Lima, Diogo Xavier; Alves, Maria Helena; Santiago, André Luiz Cabral Monteiro de Azevedo
Nova Hedwigia, (2021), p. 353 - 359

Abstract

Syncephalis plumigaleata is being described for the first time from South America. The fungus was found parasitizing Pilobolus sp. growing on horse dung samples collected in Recife, Pernambuco, Brazil. So far, this species has been found in Austria, India, Malaysia, Sri Lanka, the United States of America, and Zimbabwe. In this manuscript we describe and illustrate the Brazilian specimen, and aspects of its morphology are discussed. This work contributes to the knowledge of Zoopagales distribution.

item.title: Non-hypocrealean ascomycetes on Frullania mainly from Southeastern North America
item.description:
Non-hypocrealean ascomycetes on Frullania mainly from Southeastern North America

Döbbeler, Peter; Davison, Paul G.
Nova Hedwigia, (2021), p. 361 - 401

Abstract

This contribution is a study of the non-hypocrealean fruit-body forming ascomycetes (Chaetothyriales, Helotiales, Pezizales, Verrucariales) on common bark-inhabiting Frullania species (Frullaniaceae, Porellales, Jungermanniopsida) mainly from Southeastern North America (U.S.A., Alabama, Georgia, Mississippi, Missouri, North Carolina, Tennessee, Virginia). Some records from Northeastern North America (Canada, New Brunswick; U.S.A., Maine, New Hampshire) and from Europe are included. Frullania specimens gathered from about 1100 trees were visually screened, many of them co-infected by hypocrealean ascomycetes treated in a previous study. The following 12 non-hypocrealean species based on about 240 records were found to occur in North America: Epibryon muscicola, Filicupula cyanopoda sp. nov., F. sororia sp. nov., Hypobryon bacillare, H. florentinum, Muellerella frullaniae, M. rubescens, Octosporella brevibarbata sp. nov., O. caudifera sp. nov., O. imitatrix sp. nov., Pithyella chalaudii, P. trigona sp. nov. Several of these species were previously known from Europe and have North American Frullania species as new hosts. Apart from Frullania, Radula complanata is a new host for Muellerella frullaniae, and Cheilolejeunea clypeata is a new host for Pithyella chalaudii. Worldwide there are currently 38 species of ascomycetes known on 13 host species of Frullania. More species of bryophilous ascomycetes parasitize Frullania than any other bryophyte genus. Seventeen species belong to the Hypocreales, ten to the Pezizales, and 11 to other orders. In the North American Frullania species, ascomycete species richness is highest on Frullania inflata (11 species), in Europe on F. dilatata (14 species). Most species of non-hypocrealean ascomycetes exhibit a biotrophic lifestyle in combination with specificity to one or few host species. Ascomata occur on or between the leaves, less often on the ventral side of the leaf lobe perforating the leaves or protruding just beyond the leaf border. Non-hypocrealean species parasitizing juvenile sporophytes within the perianths as in the hypocrealean genus Periantria have not been observed. A key and a short overview of non-hypo­crealean frullaniicolous ascomycetes hitherto known are given.

item.title: A critical catalogue of Exobasidiales (Exobasidiomycetes, Basidiomycota) of north-temperate Eurasia
item.description:
A critical catalogue of Exobasidiales (Exobasidiomycetes, Basidiomycota) of north-temperate Eurasia

Dudka, Vasilii A.; Zmitrovich, Ivan V.
Nova Hedwigia, (2021), p. 403 - 427

Abstract

The present paper is devoted to expand the understanding of the geography of the Exobasidiales order over areas of cold and northern part of the temperate belt of northern Eurasia (Russia) on the basis of the herbarium collection of the Botanical Institute of the Russian Academy of Sciences (LE). In total, in the cold and northern part of the temperate belt of northern Eurasia (Russia), we noted 27 species belonging to the genera Arcticomyces (1 species), Exobasidium (25 species), and Graphiola (1 species). All 380 LE specimens included into the present catalogue were morphologically investigated by us. It should be noted that Graphiola phoenicis dosn’t occur in natural habitats of the temperate zone and is included by us as an additional material due to the fact, that it is often found on artificially planted palms in greenhouses and indoor areas. An exhaustive original description is given for each species. All the herbarium documentation is given for each species and the most of species are illustrated.

item.title: Morphology and DNA phylogeny differentiate several anamorphic ascomycetes associated with a cereal cyst nematode, Heterodera filipjevi, and new records for the mycobiota of Iran
item.description:
Morphology and DNA phylogeny differentiate several anamorphic ascomycetes associated with a cereal cyst nematode, Heterodera filipjevi, and new records for the mycobiota of Iran

Karimpour, Elnaz; Niknam, Gholamreza; Khodaei, Sima; Arzanlou, Mahdi
Nova Hedwigia, (2021), p. 429 - 451

Abstract

Heterodera filipjevi is one of the widely distributed cyst nematodes of cereals, causing significant yield losses. This species has been reported from many wheat-producing areas in Iran, including East Azarbaijan province. During the surveys on fungal species associated with H. filipjevi cyst nematode in East Azarbaijan province, several fungal isolates were recovered from shells, egg suspensions, and whole cysts. Integration of cultural and morphological characteristics with sequence data of ITS-rDNA differentiated Auxarthron alboluteum, Exophiala equina, Juxtiphoma eupyrena, Oidiodendron cereale, Periconia macrospinosa and Pleotrichocladium opacum from the cysts of H. filipjevi for the first time worldwide. Additionally, A. alboluteum, J. eupyrena, O. cereale and P. opacum represent new records for the mycobiota of Iran. Here we provide descriptions, fully illustrate these species and further discuss their ecology, host range, and geographical distribution. Their antagonistic potential and pathogenicity on this nematode remain to be studied.
